subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Tibetan Buddhism: Monks, Mandalas, and the Dalai Lama
description: A quick, practical guide to Tibetan Buddhism: Monks, Mandalas, and the Dalai Lama.

hook.text: They spend weeks building sand art, then destroy it in seconds. Tibetan Buddhism turns destruction into enlightenment.

buildup.text: Tibetan Buddhism blends Indian Buddhism with local Bon shamanism. It's rich in ritual, chanting, and visualization.

discovery.text: Mandalas are cosmic maps of colored sand. Destroying them teaches impermanence: nothing lasts, and that is the lesson.

twist.text: The Dalai Lama, once an obscure monk, became a global celebrity. Exile by China made Tibetan Buddhism world-famous.

climax.text: Tibet lost its country but won the world's attention. Suffering, in Buddhist irony, became the teacher once again.

punchline.text: Tibet lost its land but won the world. Suffering became the teacher.

quiz.question: Why do Tibetan monks destroy sand mandalas?
options: To teach the Buddhist principle of impermanence
